actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on March 9, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Johnson (LA) moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 140 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Comer moved that the committee rise.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Jackson Lee amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 209
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 207

actions-list.actionItem: The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 140 — "To amend title 5, United States Code, to prohibit Federal employees from advocating for censorship of viewpoints in their official capacity, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 426
actions-list.actionItem: 0 (Roll no. 137).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 753 — "To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to use on-site regulated medical waste treatment systems at certain Department of Veterans Affairs facilities, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 103

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Con. Res. 21 — "Directing the President, pursuant to section 5(c) of the War Powers Resolution, to remove the United States Armed Forces from Syria."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to H. Con. Res. 21; motion to suspend the rules and pass H.R. 753, as amended; and on adoption of amendments to H.R. 140, which had all been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 8.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 140 as unfinished business.
On motion that the Committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Comer moved that the Committee rise.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 8.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 8 printed in House Report 118-7 to revise the civil penalty for senior government officials to be $50,000.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 7.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 7 printed in House Report 118-7 to revise the disciplinary action consisting of removal, reduction in grade, debarment from federal employment for a period not to exceed 10 years, suspension, or reprimand.

At the conclusion of debate on the Jackson Lee amendment No. 6, the Chair put the question on adoption of the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Ms. Jackson Lee demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings on the question of adoption of the amendment until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Jackson Lee amendment No. 6.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Jackson Lee,  numbered 6 printed in House Report 118-7 to strike section 2(e).
On agreeing to the Good (VA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Good (VA) amendment No. 5.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Good (VA),  numbered 5 printed in House Report 118-7 to clarify enforcement of obscene matters not protected by the First Amendment.

At the conclusion of debate on the Perry amendment No. 4, the Chair put the question on adoption of the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Fitzpatrick demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings on the question of adoption of the amendment until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No.4.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 4 printed in House Report 118-7 to ensure that federal employees entering into collective bargaining agreements using taxpayer funded time (Section 7131) are prohibited from engaging in censorship of private entities.
On agreeing to the Bishop (NC) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Bishop (NC) amendment No. 3.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Bishop (NC),  numbered 3 printed in House Report 118-7 to ensure that law enforcement can only take action against unlawful speech.
On agreeing to the Comer amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Comer amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Comer,  numbered 2 printed in House Report 118-7 to make technical edits and to add a conforming clarification for the authorities of the Office of the Special Counsel to ensure that the Act's monetary civil penalties under new section 7382(c)(2) can be fully enforced.
On agreeing to the Clyde amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Clyde amendment No. 1.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Clyde,  numbered 1 printed in House Report 118-7 to require the Attorney General to submit an annual report to Congress evaluating the compliance of the Federal Government with the Protecting Free Speech from Government Interference Act. This amendment provides transparency and insight into any potential violations of the Act by government agencies or employees, and sunsets after 10 years.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 140.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Flood to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 199 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 140, H.J. Res. 27 and S. 619. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 140, under a structured rule. The resolution provides for consideration of H.J. Res. 27 and S. 619, under closed rules. General debate is limited to one hour of debate on all measures.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 199. H.R. 140 — "To amend title 5, United States Code, to prohibit Federal employees from advocating for censorship of viewpoints in their official capacity, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H. Con. Res. 21, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Gaetz demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings on agreeing to the resolution until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to a previous  order of the House.
Pursuant to a previous order of the House, the House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Con. Res. 21.
Considered pursuant to a previous order. H. Con. Res. 21 — "Directing the President, pursuant to section 5(c) of the War Powers Resolution, to remove the United States Armed Forces from Syria."
Consideration initiated pursuant to a previous order.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 216
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 217

actions-list.actionItem: The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 199.
On agreeing to the Massie amendment; Agreed to without objection.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Massie, Amendment strikes section 4 of the resolution and redesignates the subesequent section accordingly.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 199 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 140) to amend title 5, United States Code, to prohibit Federal employees from advocating for censorship of viewpoints in their official capacity, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 27) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Department of the Army, Corps of Engineers, Department of Defense and the Environmental Protection Agency relating to "Revised Definition of 'Waters of the United States'"; and providing for consideration of the bill (S. 619) to require the Director of National Intelligence to declassify information relating to the origin of COVID-19, and for other purposes."

Mr. Massie asked for unanimous consent that it be in order at any time to consider H. Con. Res. 21 in the House if called up by the chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs or his designee; that the concurrent resolution be considered as read; that the previous question be considered as ordered on the concurrent resolution to adoption without intervening motion except for one hour of debate equally divided among and controlled by Representative McCaul, Representative Meeks, and Representative Gaetz or their respective designees; and that the provisions of section 7 of the War Powers, Resolution, 50 U.S.C 1546, shall not apply to H. Con. Res. 20. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 205 — "Electing Members to certain standing committees of the House of Representatives and ranking a Member on a certain standing committee of the House of Representatives."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Valadao to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 8.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Marjorie Taylor Greene to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
